areaDesc.2: Gradually slopes from Mammoth Road and from Sunnyside Street toward Porter Street which is low.
areaDesc.3: Street car line continues to Mammoth Rd.
areaDesc.4: Low land around Porter Street where there is poor drainage. Unimproved streets.

5.a: shoe workers and small business people

areaDesc.14: Just West of Mammoth and Cilly Roads, E. M. Chase has built about 15 cheap brick boxlike singles on narrow lots all alike. On the other hand Sundeen Construction Co. has built 8 or 10 small frame singles of a much better character, near Mammoth Road and on Candia Road.

areaDesc.2: Low lying valley through which runs a brook, tributary to the Merrimack, although the brook is being piped by W.P.A.
areaDesc.3: Zoned for general residence
areaDesc.4: Almost entirely undeveloped. No transportation facilities. Unimproved streets. No schools. Only Eve St. built up
areaDesc.14: Many of these cottages have been built by the owners themselves with no plan or design. Although several streets are shown on the map, they are not actually laid out.

areaDesc.2: Gradual slope west from Beacon Street.
areaDesc.3: Close in. Near schools and churches. East portion high. Good street car transportation.
areaDesc.4: Western portion congested old buildings, some built over 60 years ago. Tenements. Many houses without modern plumbing and heating equipment
areaDesc.14: Portion west of Wilson Street is the poorest part of the area; poorer classes Polish people, congested rows old wooden tenements in poor condition.

areaDesc.2: Gradual slope toward river
areaDesc.3: Proximity to business center, schools and churches.
areaDesc.4: Adjacent to manufacturing section and main railroad line. Very old/mill houses in fair to poor condition brick
areaDesc.14: These properties until 1936 were owned by the Amoskeag Mfg Co. and rented only to employes. Rents have been raised by Amoskeag Industries inc., the new owners. The northern part of this area is the best and newest, and tenements are rented from $18 to $24 per month per unit. Other buildings in the area are gradually being sold for business & some have been remodelled into office buildings.

areaDesc.2: High and slightly along Union Street with gradual slope East and West.
areaDesc.3: Sightly. Not entirely built up but existing houses are of best construction. Grounds well planned. Good streets. Little traffic. No industrial noises or smoke.
areaDesc.4: None at Union St. River Road low. Railroad tracks at the river bank.
areaDesc.14: Smaller units suffered less decline in value than the older large singles

areaDesc.2: Wooded land north of Bridge St. Gradual slope southeast
areaDesc.3: General residence zoning. Street car transportation. School and churches.
areaDesc.4: Through highway and railroad. Now very sparsely settled. Unimproved streets. City water not available north of Bridge Street except at owners' expense.
areaDesc.14: Large families of small income interested in truck gardening and chickens

areaDesc.2: High, hilly, sparsely settled, wooded around Stevens' pond. Bridge St. main thoroughfare.
areaDesc.3: High and dry. Sightly. Grade school. Street car transportation
areaDesc.4: Unimproved streets. Unattractive houses and arrangement. Artificial pond for ice cutting at Ohio & Connecticut Aves.

5.a: French, Polish & Greek, Italian shoe workers

areaDesc.2: Flat. Low north of railroad tracks
areaDesc.3: Near schools and churches. Zoned for general residence.
areaDesc.4: Railroad tracks. Largely undeveloped except along Candia Road. Low and inclined to be swampy north of railroad tracks. Oil tanks and junk yards near Portsmouth Avenue.
areaDesc.14: sparsely settled

areaDesc.2: Gradual slope west from Hall Street.
areaDesc.3: Practically all zoned for general residence. Good schools and churches. Street car transportation 10 minutes to downtown. Generally pride of home ownership, especially East of Hall St.
areaDesc.4: Proximity to factories and railroad tracks.
areaDesc.14: Within six months about 15 new frame single cottages have been built in the neighborhood of Roy Ave and also Vinton Street. Area sparsely settled south of Howe Street.

areaDesc.2: High point at South Beach and Gold Streets. Gradual slope North and East. Rolling country West of S. Beach St.
areaDesc.3: Near Pine Island Park. Mostly zoned for general residence. Street car transportation. School.
areaDesc.4: Near three cemeteries. Largely undeveloped, and unimproved streets.

areaDesc.2: Gradual slope west to river. Rocky brush land
areaDesc.3: Mostly zoned for general residences
areaDesc.4: Largely undeveloped; unimproved streets below Brown Ave; away from schools, churches; transportation inconvenient
areaDesc.14: Poorer classes of people in cheap frame houses

areaDesc.2: Level land
areaDesc.3: Street car transportation; playground, 10 minutes walk to schools and churches; neighborhood stores; improved streets
areaDesc.4: Surrounded by industrial area; two through highways

areaDesc.2: High and dry. Slopes East and West from Highland Street.
areaDesc.3: Sightly. Near Derryfield Park and Derryfield Country Club. Street car transportation on Lake Ave. Good pride of home ownership.
areaDesc.4: Traffic on Hanover St. which is a main highway.

areaDesc.2: High point at Ashland St. Gradual slope west
areaDesc.3: Near grade and high schools and churches. Close in. Street car transportation.
areaDesc.4: Very old section. Houses not kept in good repair. A large number of old sheds and barns now abandoned. Irregular streets.

6.a: Conglomerate mixture of multi-fam. and cheap singles

7.6: Impossible to determine because of presence of various types old obsolete buildings. Some remodelled. Rents would average $15 a month.

areaDesc.2: Slightly sloping to South and West. Fully built up, one of the old sections of the city.
areaDesc.3: Close in. Civic center around Beech and Concord Streets.
areaDesc.4: Large old singles. Traffic. Clubs and societies.
areaDesc.14: Several old frame tenements in the area renting from $25_$35 a month per unit.

areaDesc.2: West portion level with a gradual rise to the east.
areaDesc.3: Civic center. 5 to 10 minutes walk to business center. Many schools and churches. Playgrounds and parks.
areaDesc.4: Congested houses in poor condition. Number of large old singles converted into two or more apartments.
areaDesc.14: In section bounded by Beech, Auburn, Chestnut, and Manchester Sts are to be found many vacant houses, partly boarded up and others which have not been painted in the last 25 years; inhabited by a mixture of foreign people.

areaDesc.2: Fairly level.
areaDesc.3: Close in. Schools and churches. Playground. Park. East of Wilson Street best of area.
areaDesc.4: Zoned for commercial use between Beech and Wilson Streets and zoned for apartments West of Beech. Incinerator and City Yard adjacent to the south.

5.f: many in E. portion, Few in W. "

6.a: multi family tenements and small singles

areaDesc.14: Best of the section is East of Wilson St. where small singles are in good repair and show evidence of prode of home ownership.

areaDesc.2: High along Belmont Street with gradual slope West towards river.
areaDesc.3: Zoned for general residence. Good streets. Close in. Good pride of home ownership. Good street car transportation.
areaDesc.4: Traffic. Webster Street a main thoroughfare through the area. State Orphan School corner Beech & Webster.
areaDesc.14: There are three main streets in the area over which a considerable amount of traffic moves.

areaDesc.2: Gradual downward slope toward the East. Wooded land sparsely settled.
areaDesc.3: High. Adjacent to the best probable future development. Sightly. Freedom from noise and traffic.
areaDesc.4: As yet undeveloped. Only Arah Street is completed.
areaDesc.14: 80% of structures in the area are on Arah Street. Balance of area now very sparsley settled. Most of building has taken place since 1929.

areaDesc.2: High level land. Sparsely settled north of Mason St. Partly rock ledges.
areaDesc.3: Rock Rimmon Park and municipal swimming pool. Street car and bus transportation adequate. Good schools and churches. Zoned for general residence.
areaDesc.4: Houses old congested closely built in the southern part of the area. 15-20 minutes' ride to down-town business center. Generally poorer classes on side of river.

5.a: French mill workers & small business men

areaDesc.14: Houses along Coolidge Ave average about $7,000 in value. These are frame singles about 10 yrs old in good condition set apart with lawns and shrubbery. Just below Coolidge Ave to the east the land drops off precipitously about 30 ft to Area D4 and is the location of a city dump

areaDesc.2: Low land
areaDesc.3: near mills. Schools. Churches
areaDesc.4: Proximity to manufacturing area and river and very sparsely settled. Unimproved roads. Exposed to flood damage. Near ice houses
areaDesc.14: The northern strip of this area along the river bank is occupied by summer colonists in single frame summer cottages in good condition valued at an average of about $1,000. These are in a single line at the river edge. There are no other houses in this sector.

areaDesc.2: Gradual slope south and east of Gossler Park. Low land west of the park known as "The Flats".
areaDesc.3: Good schools and churches, adequate transportation. Gossler Park an amusement center. West of the park zoned for general residence. Close to mills.
areaDesc.4: Flooded near the Piscataquog River in 1936. East of Gossler Park zoned for apartments and a great many 6 tenement houses are now to be found here.

5.a: Mixed foreign mill workers and cigar makers

areaDesc.14: Amony St. is about 30 ft. above the adjacent "flats" to which it is connected by a cement stairway at Bartlett St. Access to the "flats" only from Blucker St. on the south; Putnam St. from the East or Bartlett St. on the North. Dubuque and Cartier are dead end streets coming up abruptly to a 40 foot sand bank.

areaDesc.2: High near the center and sloping toward both rivers.
areaDesc.3: near West Manchester business center and high school. Good grade schools, churches and transportation.
areaDesc.4: Railroad and a considerable number of old houses in poor repair. One of the oldest sections of the west side.
areaDesc.14: Wet wash laundry and a shoe shop near the Piscataquog river in area flooded Spring of 1936

areaDesc.2: Rolling country, gradually rising from the river. Largely undeveloped open fields to the southwest.
areaDesc.3: Quiet section. Not much through traffic. Schools and churches. Good street car transportation as well as bus lines.
areaDesc.4: Danger of floods near the two rivers. Oldest part on the West side. Many houses not equipped with modern heating and plumbing.
areaDesc.14: The best of this section lies between Mast and Boynton Streets where some professional people and business executives live with an average income of approximately $6,000

areaDesc.2: High along Brown Ave. Steep incline to river.
areaDesc.3: Street car transportation; adjacent to Pine Island Park, a summer resport, school, churches and business center in vicinity.
areaDesc.4: Exposed to flood damage
areaDesc.14: A separate little community with its own stores, churches, schools and branch post office. Near Manchester's new airport. This is section is known as Goffs Falls. Fleischer Shoe Co. has a factory at this point.
